subdefinitions.definition: To intend , to plan (to do); to have as one's intention.
examples: I didn't mean to knock your tooth out.
I mean to go to Arévalo in Spainn this summer; been mean ing to tell you for weeks, but I've just found the time.
I meant to take the car in for a smog check, but it slipped my mind.
The authors meant a challenge to the status quo.
Do you mean to say you regret it after all ?

subdefinitions.definition: To have as intentions of a given kind.
examples: Don't be angry; she meant well.

subdefinitions.definition: To intend (something) for a given purpose or fate; to predestine .
examples: Actually this desk was meant for the subeditor.
Man was not meant to question such things.

subdefinitions.definition: To intend an ensuing comment or statement as an explanation.
examples: Your reasoning seems needlessly abstruse, complex, and verbose for me. I mean , could you dumb it down for my sake?

subdefinitions.definition: To convey (a given sense); to signify , or indicate (an object or idea).
examples: The sky is red this morning—does that mean we're in for a storm?

subdefinitions.definition: Of a word, symbol etc: to have reference to, to signify .
Of a person (or animal etc): to intend to express , to imply , to hint at, to allude .
examples: I'm afraid I don't understand what you mean .
He's a little different, if you know what I mean .

definitions.definition: To have conviction in (something said or expressed); to be sincere in (what one says).
examples: Does she really mean what she said to him last night?
Say what you mean and mean what you say.

definitions.definition: To cause or produce (a given result ); to bring about (a given result).
examples: One faltering step means certain death.
This breakthrough will mean that we spend less on electricity bills.

definitions.definition: To be of some level of importance.
examples: That little dog meant everything to me.
Formality and titles mean nothing in their circle.

secondary_definitions: ( transitive ) To have conviction in (something said or expressed); to be sincere in (what one says). [from 18th c.]
( transitive ) To cause or produce (a given result ); to bring about (a given result). [from 19th c.]
( usually with to ) To be of some level of importance.
